item.title: Nokia's Famously Indestructible Phone Rumored To Be Returning To Shelves
item.description: February 15, 2017 - Launched in 2000, the Nokia 3310 was a rugged little brick that won Internet fame for its durability. There are rumors, which HMD Global won't confirm, that the company is bringing the phone back.
item.itunes:summary: February 15, 2017 - Launched in 2000, the Nokia 3310 was a rugged little brick that won Internet fame for its durability. There are rumors, which HMD Global won't confirm, that the company is bringing the phone back. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/15/515419519/nokias-famously-indestructible-phone-rumored-to-be-returning-to-shelves

item.title: Indian IT Outsourcers Anxious Over Potential Changes To H1-B Visas
item.description: February 14, 2017 - President Trump vows to "protect jobs at home." Indian firms say that if there were qualified Americans, Indian nationals wouldn't be needed — that it's a trade dispute, not an immigration issue.
item.itunes:summary: February 14, 2017 - President Trump vows to "protect jobs at home." Indian firms say that if there were qualified Americans, Indian nationals wouldn't be needed — that it's a trade dispute, not an immigration issue. http://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2017/02/14/515232929/indian-it-outsourcers-anxious-over-potential-changes-to-h1-b-visas

item.title: In America's Heartland, A Power Company Leads Charge For Electric Cars
item.description: February 14, 2017 - Kansas City Power & Light is building an ambitious, $20 million network of 1,000 charging stations. It's turning its service area into one of the fastest-growing electric vehicle markets in the U.S.
item.itunes:summary: February 14, 2017 - Kansas City Power & Light is building an ambitious, $20 million network of 1,000 charging stations. It's turning its service area into one of the fastest-growing electric vehicle markets in the U.S. http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/02/14/514517425/in-americas-heartland-a-power-company-leads-charge-for-electric-cars

item.title: Disney Company Drops YouTube Star PewDiePie Over Anti-Semitic Jokes
item.description: February 14, 2017 - More than 50 million people are subscribed to videos by gamer and comedian Felix Kjellberg. Now he's lost a lucrative contract with a Disney-owned firm, The Wall Street Journal reports.
item.itunes:summary: February 14, 2017 - More than 50 million people are subscribed to videos by gamer and comedian Felix Kjellberg. Now he's lost a lucrative contract with a Disney-owned firm, The Wall Street Journal reports. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/14/515184619/disney-company-drops-youtube-star-pewdiepie-over-anti-semitic-jokes

item.title: With More Rain Forecast, Crews Work To Reinforce Oroville Dam
item.description: February 14, 2017 - Water damage to an emergency spillway on the Oroville Dam in Northern California prompted the evacuation of nearly 200,000 people from the area. More rain is forecast for the region this week.
item.itunes:summary: February 14, 2017 - Water damage to an emergency spillway on the Oroville Dam in Northern California prompted the evacuation of nearly 200,000 people from the area. More rain is forecast for the region this week. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/14/515172686/with-more-rain-forecast-crews-work-to-reinforce-oroville-dam

item.title: Is Donald Trump Helping Or Hurting Twitter?
item.description: February 14, 2017 - The tweeter-in-chief has brought a new level of notoriety to the social media company, but it hasn't helped Twitter's bottom line. Analysts say Trump-related harassment continues to hurt the platform.
item.itunes:summary: February 14, 2017 - The tweeter-in-chief has brought a new level of notoriety to the social media company, but it hasn't helped Twitter's bottom line. Analysts say Trump-related harassment continues to hurt the platform. http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/02/14/515024727/is-donald-trump-helping-or-hurting-twitter

item.title: Using H-1B Visas To Help Outsource IT Work Draws Criticism, Scrutiny
item.description: February 13, 2017 - A number of companies and universities are cutting IT jobs and shipping them off to India. The practice has drawn scrutiny amid the debate over how H1-B visas for high-skilled workers are used.
item.itunes:summary: February 13, 2017 - A number of companies and universities are cutting IT jobs and shipping them off to India. The practice has drawn scrutiny amid the debate over how H1-B visas for high-skilled workers are used. http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/02/13/514990545/using-h-1b-visas-to-help-outsource-it-work-draws-criticism-scrutiny

item.title: Rollout Of Chevy Bolt May Mark Turning Point For Electric Car Market
item.description: February 13, 2017 - The Chevy Bolt can go 238 miles on a single charge and costs about $30,000, after a federal tax credit. But the clean-car industry needs government support to thrive, and that's far from certain.
item.itunes:summary: February 13, 2017 - The Chevy Bolt can go 238 miles on a single charge and costs about $30,000, after a federal tax credit. But the clean-car industry needs government support to thrive, and that's far from certain. http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/02/13/514513439/rollout-of-chevy-bolt-may-mark-turning-point-for-electric-car-market

item.title: A $40,000 Drone Failed To Lift Off. But There Was A Silver Lining
item.description: February 13, 2017 - A drone test in a remote Amazonian village in Peru failed. And that, says one of the testers, was the best possible outcome.
item.itunes:summary: February 13, 2017 - A drone test in a remote Amazonian village in Peru failed. And that, says one of the testers, was the best possible outcome. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/02/13/514988364/a-40-000-drone-failed-to-lift-off-but-there-was-a-silver-lining

item.title: 'Aisles Have Eyes' Warns That Brick-And-Mortar Stores Are Watching You
item.description: February 13, 2017 - Consumers have grown accustomed to the idea of online retailers collecting information about them, but author Joseph Turow says that now physical stores are doing it too.
item.itunes:summary: February 13, 2017 - Consumers have grown accustomed to the idea of online retailers collecting information about them, but author Joseph Turow says that now physical stores are doing it too. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/13/514322899/aisles-have-eyes-warns-that-brick-and-mortar-stores-are-watching-you

item.title: Reading The Game: The Flame In The Flood
item.description: February 12, 2017 - In The Flame in the Flood, you play as a young girl surviving in a post-apocalyptic landscape, floating down a river on an improvised raft, with nothing but your wits and your faithful dog beside you.
item.itunes:summary: February 12, 2017 - In The Flame in the Flood, you play as a young girl surviving in a post-apocalyptic landscape, floating down a river on an improvised raft, with nothing but your wits and your faithful dog beside you. http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/02/12/514386766/reading-the-game-the-flame-in-the-flood

item.title: Ajit Pai Starts To Roll Back Latest Internet Regulations From Obama's Team
item.description: February 11, 2017 - The new head of the Federal Communications Commission has taken steps to unravel many of his predecessor's policies. These changes might directly affect consumers and their access to the Internet.
item.itunes:summary: February 11, 2017 - The new head of the Federal Communications Commission has taken steps to unravel many of his predecessor's policies. These changes might directly affect consumers and their access to the Internet. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/11/514732239/ajit-pai-starts-to-roll-back-latest-internet-regulations-from-obamas-team

item.title: 'Wired' Declares Coding As Next Blue-Collar Job Boom
item.description: February 10, 2017 - This week, an article in Wired declared, "The Next Big Blue-Collar Job Is Coding." NPR's Kelly McEvers speaks with reporter Clive Thompson about the article.
item.itunes:summary: February 10, 2017 - This week, an article in Wired declared, "The Next Big Blue-Collar Job Is Coding." NPR's Kelly McEvers speaks with reporter Clive Thompson about the article. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/10/514566974/wired-declares-coding-as-next-blue-collar-job-boom

item.title: 'Migrant Hire' Connects Refugees To German Tech Industry
item.description: February 10, 2017 - With an aging population and skilled labor shortage, German industry leaders view the almost million migrants who have arrived since 2015 as an opportunity. But integrating them quickly into the labor market is a challenge. Syrian refugee Hussein Shaker may have the answer. He's founded Migrant Hire, a website that helps refugees with software development skills obtain jobs in the capital's lively tech scene.
item.itunes:summary: February 10, 2017 - With an aging population and skilled labor shortage, German industry leaders view the almost million migrants who have arrived since 2015 as an opportunity. But integrating them quickly into the labor market is a challenge. Syrian refugee Hussein Shaker may have the answer. He's founded Migrant Hire, a website that helps refugees with software development skills obtain jobs in the capital's lively tech scene. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/10/514566961/migrant-hire-connects-refugees-to-german-tech-industry

item.title: Denmark's Foreign Service Will Soon Send An Ambassador To The Tech World
item.description: February 10, 2017 - Danish Foreign Minister Anders Samuelsen says the new diplomatic post is a nod to the digital world's impact on people's day-to-day lives, which he says is greater than most nations' impact.
item.itunes:summary: February 10, 2017 - Danish Foreign Minister Anders Samuelsen says the new diplomatic post is a nod to the digital world's impact on people's day-to-day lives, which he says is greater than most nations' impact. http://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2017/02/10/514170277/denmarks-foreign-service-will-soon-send-an-ambassador-to-the-tech-world
